user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileOpen_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_FileOpen_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const char *local_path, int32 flags, int32 access_mode)
{
    int                             os_perm;
    int                             os_mode;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Check for a valid access mode
    ** For creating a file, OS_READ_ONLY does not make sense
    */
    switch (access_mode)
    {
        case OS_WRITE_ONLY:
            os_perm = O_WRONLY;
            break;
        case OS_READ_ONLY:
            os_perm = O_RDONLY;
            break;
        case OS_READ_WRITE:
            os_perm = O_RDWR;
            break;
        default:
            return OS_ERROR;
    }

    if (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE)
    {
        os_perm |= O_CREAT;
    }
    if (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE)
    {
        os_perm |= O_TRUNC;
    }

    os_perm |= OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS;

    os_mode = S_IRUSR | S_IWUSR | S_IRGRP | S_IWGRP | S_IROTH | S_IWOTH;

    impl->fd = open(local_path, os_perm, os_mode);

    if (impl->fd < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("open(%s): %s\n", local_path, strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    /*
     * If the flags included O_NONBLOCK, then
     * enable the "select" call on this handle.
     */
    impl->selectable = ((os_perm & O_NONBLOCK) != 0);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileOpen_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
extern const int OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is assigned to or otherwise modified in this function. Specifically:
- The pointer parameter token is only dereferenced (*token) and its contents are used to index the object table; there is no assignment to token itself. The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET expands to use &( *token ) which yields the original pointer value but does not modify the parameter. OS_ObjectIndexFromToken merely reads token->obj_idx and does not modify the token or its pointee.
- The local_path parameter is passed to open() (which takes a const char *); it is not modified by the function.
- The scalar parameters flags and access_mode are only read (used in bit tests and a switch) and never assigned to.
- All writes in the function target local variables or the OS_impl_filehandle_table entry (impl->fd, impl->selectable). Modifying the object referred to by a pointer is permitted by Rule 17.8; no pointer parameter itself is altered.
Therefore, there are no code fragments in this function that violate or need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
